text:
Hey everyone, I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask this so please let know if not.

Does anyone here work with/as product marketing managers on larger overall marketing teams?

My company has a few core products and our marketing team has 3 PMM's who I interface with regularly. I'm running into issues where I expect them to understand certain high level things about online/digital marketing but they just... don't. The do however spend a lot of time critiquing creative and not asking our social ads specialist for advice.

I'm the Director of Digital but they don't report to me or anything, we all report up to our marketing VP.

My main Q is...is that normal? Am I expecting too much?

Really, what should product marketing managers be doing/involved with for a larger SaaS company?

Things I was expecting them to know about, or at least have opinions on the basics include:
- content marketing basics
- targeting campaigns by audience
- engaging with customers
- how to use blog posts in their campaigns effectively
- content gating

My main Q is...is that normal? Am I expecting too much?

Really, what should product marketing managers be doing/involved with for a larger SaaS company?

Things I was expecting them to know about, or at least have opinions on the basics include:

- content gating

text: Having worked at a big tech firm before with other PMMs, I would say knowing some of the digital concepts is standard. The current PMM I work with sounds like the opposite of your PMM. He critiques creative and copy once in awhile, but spends most of his time scheduling and coordinating when and how the message gets out. While it does require knowledge of digital, I would say the PMM’s role is much more encompassing because he or she needs to understand risk factors with new features that get released, how power users vs new users might experience the feature, etc.

elements.text: Having worked at a big tech firm before with other PMMs, I would say knowing some of the digital concepts is standard. The current PMM I work with sounds like the opposite of your PMM. He critiques creative and copy once in awhile, but spends most of his time scheduling and coordinating when and how the message gets out. While it does require knowledge of digital, I would say the PMM’s role is much more encompassing because he or she needs to understand risk factors with new features that get released, how power users vs new users might experience the feature, etc.

text: Hey Kyle, in my experience, it really depends on the PMMs. Most of the PMMs I’ve worked with act mainly as a source of information about the product—they share their insights on what the most marketable parts of the products are for certain audiences, information about those audiences and what they’re interested/not interested in... Rarely do they critique creative. I’d say all of the requirements you listed are things that they all have had, though I’m not sure if it’s a must-have requirement for the PMM job. Hope that helps.
